cs.DS, cs.IT, cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.SI. 

The paper discusses the properties of cellular automata, which are commonly studied in computer science and discrete mathematics. The focus on causality principles suggests that the paper may belong to the cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) sub-category, which often deals with causal relationships between data elements. Additionally, the paper discusses probabilistic processes and Markov chains, which are commonly studied in the cs.IT (Information Theory) sub-category. The use of machine learning techniques and the investigation of non-locality suggest that the paper may also belong to the cs.LG (Machine Learning) and cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) sub-categories. Finally, the paper's focus on non-signalling and common cause principles suggests that it may also belong to the cs.SI (Social and Information Networks) sub-category, which often deals with communication and information flow in complex systems.
